Project Description  The Project will establish a coal mine methane development project 
(CMMDP) at Jincheng in the southern part of Shanxi Province with 
the following components: (i) Part A, coalbed methane (CBM) and 
coal  mine  methane  (CMM)  production  for  a  power  plant  of  120 
megawatts (MW); (ii) Part B, CMM transmission and distribution to 
consumers  in  the  Jincheng  area;  and  (iii)  Part  C,  institutional 
strengthening and capacity building.  
 
Rationale  In 2003, the People’s Republic of China (PRC) produced about 1.7 
billion tons of coal. Coal mining causes the release of methane, a 
greenhouse gas (GHG), which is about 21 times more potent than 
carbon dioxide (CO ), into the atmosphere. PRC coal mines release 
2
more than 6 billion cubic meters (m3) of methane each year. With 
increasing coal production and depth of coal mining, this amount will 
increase. Methane is highly explosive and needs to be removed 
(drained)  during  underground  coal  mining  operations  to  keep 
working conditions safe. Each year at least 7,000 miners die from 
underground  accidents,  mainly  caused  by  methane  explosions. 
Therefore,  increased  removal,  capture,  and  use  of  methane  will 
(i) reduce GHG emissions, (ii) increase clean fuel use (methane in 
place of coal), (iii) improve air quality, and (iv) improve coal mine 
safety and efficiency. The increased production and use of CMM and 
CBM require new technologies that are not yet used in the PRC. 
A project demonstrating that such new technologies can be applied 
in  the  PRC  would  catalyze  development  of  similar  projects 
elsewhere  in  the  country.  Southern  Shanxi  Province  has  highly 
methane-rich coal mines. After careful study of potential coal mining 
areas by Asian Development Bank (ADB)-financed consultants, the 
area around Jincheng was selected as most suitable for establishing 
a demonstration project. Part A of the Project will demonstrate the 
more  efficient  production  of  CBM,  and  drainage  and  capture  of 
CMM, and their use for power generation as a least-cost alternative

  using  new  technologies.  Part  B  will  demonstrate  the  efficient 
commercial  use  of  CMM  for  transmission  and  distribution  to 
consumers.  Part  C  will  institutionally  strengthen  the  companies 
involved in the CMMDP and promote similar projects in the PRC.  
   
Objective  The  main  objective  of  the  CMMDP  is  to  establish  a  CMM 
development project that covers all aspects of effective and efficient 
CMM and CBM production, capture, and utilization by applying the 
latest  technologies,  i.e.,  improved  CBM  production  from  vertical 
surface wells and directionally drilled wells from the surface into 
underground coal seams, improved CMM drainage through the use 
of underground directional drilling and other modern equipment and 
materials, CMM-based power generation using internal combustion 
gas  engines,  and  transmission  and  distribution  of  CMM  for 
residential,  commercial,  and  industrial  use.  In  this  manner  the 
CMMDP  will  improve  mine  safety,  reduce  GHG  emissions,  and 
improve the environment.

II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
2.  Economic and social development in the PRC in the last two decades has been rapid. By 
the end of 2003 the PRC’s gross domestic product (GDP) per capita was $1,000 equivalent, life 
expectancy at birth 71.4 years, and adult literacy 83%. Government programs have resulted in 
poverty reduction, particularly in rural areas. 
 
3.  Economic growth has been facilitated by infrastructure development, a crucial component 
being energy sector development. At the end of June 2004, the PRC’s total installed power was 
400 gigawatts (GW), and in 2003, total electricity generated was 1,891 terawatt-hours, 15.4% more 
than in 2002. Worldwide the PRC ranked second in installed power generation capacity and 
electricity consumption. Based on higher-than-projected growth in electricity demand from 2001 to 
2003, the 4.5-5.0% annual increase in electricity consumption forecast in the 10th Five-Year Plan 
(FYP), 2001-2005, has proved to  be too conservative and power shortages are emerging in 
various regions. Nearly three quarters of the PRC's electricity is generated by coal and a little 
under one quarter by hydroelectricity. Together, oil, gas, and nuclear power account for less than 
1%.  
 
4.  In view of the PRC's continual power shortage the Government is taking action― including 
legislation―to promote the development of renewable energy. State entities are drafting a law to 
compel power grid companies to buy electricity generated by renewable energy sources, such as 
water, wind, solar, biomass, geothermal, and marine-based power, and all end users will share the 
costs. The PRC has been slow to develop renewable energies because they are more expensive 
than conventional energy sources. However, sharp increases in energy demand leave the PRC no 
other choice than to accelerate the use of renewable energy. 
 
5.  The PRC’s coal production in 2003 was about 1.7 billion tons, 22% higher than in 2002. 
During 2004, coal production is expected to increase to about 1.9 billion tons, which will mainly be 
used in the domestic market, with only about 80.0 million tons being exported and stockpiles 
dwindling.1 Coal is expensive to transport and inefficient to use, but cheap to produce: about $12-
13 equivalent per ton for the large mines (around $6 equivalent for small ones). The PRC’s proven 
recoverable coal reserves are estimated at 114.5 billion tons.2 On this basis the PRC could 
continue the current level of coal production for 105 years. Despite the envisaged increase in use 
of natural gas following the ongoing and planned construction of the west-to- east gas transmission 
pipeline and receiving terminals for importing liquefied natural gas (LNG) along the east coast, coal 
will remain the dominant fuel with a projected share of about 64% in primary energy consumption, 
and 75% in electricity generation by 2015. Coal consumption could increase to 3.3 billion tons a 
year by 2020 assuming a continuation of the present economic growth rate and the Government’s 
energy policies.3 Appendix 2 provides an analysis of the coal sector.

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.   Objectives 
22.  The CMMDP will cover all aspects of effective and efficient CMM and CBM production, 
capture, and use by applying the latest technologies. The CMMDP will include (i) improved CBM

B.  Components and Outputs 
23.  The proposed Project components are as follows. 
1.  Part A – Production of CMM and CBM for a 120 MW Power Plant  
24.  This component includes all necessary civil works, equipment, technical and consulting 
services, and training required to (i) improve CMM drainage and degasification by drilling CBM 
surface wells at the Sihe mine, (ii) establish a 120-MW CMM-fired power plant and supply the 
required CMM and CBM35, and (iii) expand the power transmission lines and upgrade the power 
distribution systems at the coal mining areas of JMC. CMM drainage will be improved through 
directional  drilling  of  long  inseam  boreholes  underground  and  installing  CMM  gathering  and 
drainage systems. Degasification will take place as result of CBM production from surface wells 
drilled into coal seams to be developed. This will include (i) drilling of up to 20 vertical wells and 1 
directional well from the surface into coal seams, (ii) constructing gas gathering and pipeline 
transportation systems, and (iii) installing safety and monitoring systems.  The power plant will 
consist of internal combustion gas engines with an individual capacity of 1.5-3.5 MW, waste heat 
boilers, and steam turbines for power generation and will be built in two phases of 60 MW each. 
The power plant will use about 182.4 million m3 of CMM and CBM36 a year. Training will be 
provided in underground directional drilling and CMM collection, surface-well development for CBM 
production, and operation and maintenance of CMM-fired power plants. Consulting services will be 
provided  for  project  implementation  and  on-site  training.  The  general  technical  design  of  the 
CMMDP is explained in Supplementary Appendix A.

D.  Assessment of Project Risks 
  1.  CMM and CBM Production for Power Generation 
61.  The CMMDP area is among the highest potential CMM- and CBM-producing areas in terms 
of methane in place (in coal seams). The design of the CMM-fired power plant is based on a 
detailed and conservative assessment of the CMM and CBM quantities that can reasonably be 
expected to be produced during the development of the Sihe mine and has sufficient flexibility to 
accommodate any variations in the supply of CMM and CBM if they occur. In case of shortfalls of 
CMM and CBM supplies to the power plant, JMG’s mines,59 which are a few kilometers from the 
power plant, have adequate CMM production capacity and could supply additional CMM to meet 
shortfalls. The technical and completion risks associated with the introduction of new technologies 
for CBM production,60 CMM drainage, and CMM-based power generation have been addressed by 
including consulting services for project implementation, including those financed by USTDA, and 
the requirement that the supplier of the internal combustion gas engines under the CMMDP will be 
responsible for supervision of the first year  of their operation and maintenance following the 
commissioning of the first 50% of total power generation capacity. The power plant will be operated 
on  a  captive  basis  to  reduce  sensitivity  to  electric  tariffs  and,  in  principle,  will  only  produce 
electricity for the Sihe mine. However, the electricity tariff of the power plant of CNY0.234/kWh is 
lower than the average tariff of the Shanxi power grid’s average tariff of CNY0.29/kWh, and the 
power plant will be able to sell electricity to the grid in case the mine’s demand for power is 
reduced. The establishment of JMC-CU as a separate company unit with an agreed purchase price 
for the CMM and CBM and an agreed sales price to the Sihe mine for the power produced, thus 
ensuring transparency and financial sustainability of its operations. 
  2.  CMM Transmission and Distribution 
62.  The construction and operation of the CMM transmission and distribution system is based 
on a detailed technical design and known technologies. The various coal mines in the vicinity of 
Jincheng produce CMM in excess of what is required to meet the projected CMM demand under 
the CMMDP. SECC has finalized CMM purchase agreements with a sufficient number of coal 
mines to ensure adequate CMM supplies and has assigned the contracts to SECC, while SECC 
has finalized a CMM sales contract with JCCUC. The establishment of SECC as a separate entity 
will ensure financial sustainability of the operation of the pipelines. Obtaining right-of-way approval 
for construction and operation of the transmission pipelines and the feeder pipelines from the 
various coal lines to the transmission pipelines is not expected to be difficult since the pipelines 
largely run through sparsely populated areas and sufficient funds for compensation have been 
made available in accordance with the resettlement plan. The tariffs for CMM consumption are in 
line with the present tariffs for the synthetic “waste” gas, which is distributed in Jincheng, and the 
projected demand for CMM is expected to exceed supplies.

COAL SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Historical Coal Production and Consumption 
 
1.   Annual coal production in the People’s Republic of China (PRC) expanded from about 
1.05 billion tons in 1990 to about 1.40 billion tons in 1996, after which it decreased again to 
about 1.23 billion tons in 2000. Since then, these production levels were maintained at slightly 
higher levels in 2001 and 2002, only to increase sharply to about 1.6 billion tons in 2003.1 In 
1998 the demand for coal caused the Government to close about 75% of the small coal mines, 
including the township and village coal mines (TVCMs) and reduce their coal production to 
about 250 million tons a year. At the same time, coal stockpiles increased to about 200 million 
tons and exports increased to about 90 million tons a year while it was expected that given its 
relatively low coal prices the PRC could become a major coal exporter. However, since then 
coal exports have stalled at 80 million–90 million tons a year due increasing domestic demand. 
Coal is expected to continue to account for about 64% of the PRC’s primary commercial energy 
consumption and it is projected that to meet demand coal supplies would need to increase to 
about 3.2 billion tons a year by 2020 if the PRC’s present growth rates and energy policies 
continue. Although the PRC has the third largest coal reserves in the world and such coal 
demand could be met from proven domestic coal reserves, many large- and small-scale mines 
are  reaching  the  end  of  their  lifetime  cycle  and  considerable  investments  are  required  to 
increase domestic coal production. Taking into account the time required to develop new mines 
and the additional investments required for developing the required additional transportation 
infrastructure (mainly railways) to transport the coal to consumers a domestic coal supply deficit 
could occur in the future, which would need to be met from coal imports, in particular in coastal 
provinces. 
 
B.  Structure of the Coal Sector 
 
2.  Traditionally, the Ministry of Coal Industry was responsible for the PRC’s main coal 
mines. However, this ministry was abolished in 1996 and the responsibility for coal mining, 
including  the  large  state-owned  coal  mines,  was  delegated  to  the  concerned  provincial 
governments while the Government only maintained a central supervisory role through the State 
Administration for Coal Industry (SACI). Following further reorganization of the coal sector in 
1998 SACI was also abolished while the Government only remained involved in occupational 
safety aspects of the coal sector through the State Administration of Work Safety. Coal mines in 
the PRC comprise the following types: 
 
(i)  key  state-owned  coal  mines  (KSOCMs),  administered  by  the  concerned 
provincial government; 
(ii)  local state-owned coal mines (SOCMs), administered by provincial, prefecture, 
and county governments; and 
(iii)  TVCMs (operated by private individuals or local governments in townships and 
villages).  
 
3.  There are about 100 KSOCMs, of which about 33 are listed as key state enterprises. 
These mines mainly use mechanized mining technologies and their produced coal is mainly 
used in power plants, blast furnaces, steel plants, and large state-owned enterprises. There are 
about  2,000  SOCMs,  which  are  much  smaller  than  the  KSCOMs  and  are  only  partially 
mechanized. It is estimated that there are around 23,000 TVCMs, which are characterized by

local communities and townships. Before 1982, domestic coal supply was mainly provided by 
KSCOMs. It is estimated that in 2002 the KSCOMs employed about 830,000 persons, the 
SOCMs about 915,000 persons, and the TVCMs about 220,000 persons.  
 
4.  From 1983 until 1997, the Government promoted the development of TVCMs to promote 
rural development and meet coal demand in certain areas. The percentage of coal production 
from TVCMs increased from about 18% in 1980 to about 45% of total production in 1996, 
whereas during the same period the share of KSCOMs decreased from about 56% to about 
39%. Subsequently, there was a fall again in the relative share the TVCMs in coal production to 
about 19% in 2000 when overall demand for coal decreased. It is estimated that in 2002 with 
increased coal demand the share of the KSOCMs in coal production was about 51%, the share 
of the SOCMs about 19% and that of the TVCMs about 30%. Over the past decade the TVCMs 
therefore acted as “swing” coal producers to meet the domestic coal demand. 
 
5.  The considerable decreases in annual coal consumption between 1996 and 2001 have 
been largely the result of the implementation of the Government’s economic reform policies 
aimed at restructuring of the state owned enterprises and improving their operating and energy 
efficiency and financial status. In particular the Government’s policy to close small enterprises in 
the coal, power generation, petrochemicals, iron and steel, and construction materials industries 
contributed to more efficient use of coal and hence a decrease in coal consumption. Also the 
replacement of certain state-owned enterprises by more efficient commercial enterprises played 
a role. However, such efficiency gains in the use of coal have now ended and it is expected that 
coal consumption will increase considerably in the coming years driven by the sharp increase in 
demand for coal by power plants of which about 75% use coal as fuel.   
 
C.  Coal Production Cost and Pricing 
 
6.  The cost of coal production varies considerably among various mines and types of coal. 
In general, the lowest production costs occur in the TVCMs because of use of basic mining 
methods; absence of proper safety, coal mine methane (CMM) drainage, and air ventilation 
facilities; and the employment of low-wage miners. The large KSCOMs have considerable 
economies of scale in comparison with the small TVCMs but also higher costs because of 
safety, environmental, and social welfare concerns, which they need to address. Overall, it is 
estimated that in the PRC the coal production cost range between $6–15 (equivalent) per ton of 
coal produced.     
 
7.  The coal and power industries are intimately entwined: some 50% of coal production is 
used for electricity generation and more than 75% of power is generated from coal-fired plants. 
However, policies governing the two industries have not developed in step. Since the early 
1990s coal prices for other sectors than the power sector have undergone a relatively high 
degree of liberalization and prices have risen substantially, with the exception of a dip in the late 
1990s. The quantities and price of coal that the key state mines and other large coal mines are 
to supply each year to the power sector are negotiated through annual national trade coal 
conferences  with  the  participation  of  the  National  Development  and  Reform  Commission 
(NDRC) and the Ministry of Railways with the aim to arrive at a government regulated coal 
price. During recent years with considerable economic growth demand for coal has increased in 
all industrial sectors but producer and consumer prices for electricity remain tightly controlled. 
Even at times of power shortages, as occurred in 2003, power companies are not permitted to 
raise prices. This has resulted in a serious and very public conflict between the coal and power 
industries to which coal producers have responded by trying to make the power companies pay

higher prices. The Government is considering to liberalize the coal price for the power sector in 
the near future, also because considerable expansion of existing coal mines, where possible, 
and development of new ones will be required to meet the increasing demand for coal in the 
coming years. 
8.  The PRC’s membership in the World Trade Organization imposes obligations relating to 
tariff and nontariff barriers and to subsidies. However, the coal industry continues to receive 
substantial subsidies relating to extraction, transportation and social costs. Such assistance 
includes exemption of repayment of loans from state owned banks, debt-to-equity swaps to 
reduce interest costs and debts, and provision of treasury bonds and low interest loans to state 
owned coal enterprises. It is difficult to accurately estimate the past and present value of direct 
and indirect financial support provided by the Government to the coal sector. However, it is 
estimated that such support has been declining over the paste decade. This could become a 
source of contention in the near future. 
D.   Coal Transport 
9.  Although coal mining is profitable at present, transporting it by rail to large consumers 
such as power plants remains unprofitable. At present the Government allocates rail transport 
capacity for all freight, including coal, as well as freight rates. After incurring losses in the 
previous 3 years, it is estimated that the rail industry achieved marginal return on equity rates of 
0.27% to 1.13% from 1998 to 2002. However, about 50% of the freight capacity of the railways 
is already used for transporting coal and in 2004 hauling coal has become even less profitable 
for railway companies than other categories of freight, which has caused bottlenecks in the 
supply of coal and has worsened coal shortages. Under these circumstances securing adequate 
railway capacity for transporting coal in the future has become a major challenge.

1.  The Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) is a market-based financing instrument under 
the Kyoto Protocol. It provides project developers access to additional financial resources for 
developing and implementing projects that provide greenhouse gas (GHG) reduction benefits 
over business-as-usual trends. The enforcement of the Kyoto Protocol is expected shortly with 
ratification by Russia. The amount of $1.5 billion–2.5 billion has been committed in the GHG

approaches, to $5 billion–10 billion annually. 
 
2.  Emission reductions created by the Coal Mine Methane Development Project (CMMDP) 
may qualify for trading under the CDM. Under the CDM, emission reductions in a developing 
country can be traded or sold to developed countries subject to GHG reduction targets under 
the Kyoto Protocol. The CDM process has five steps: (i) identification and design, including 
preparation of a project design document; (ii) validation and registration with the CDM executive 
board; (iii) monitoring; (iv) verification and certification; and (v) issuance of certified emission 
reductions (CERs).

SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  This  document  summarizes  the  potential  environmental  impacts  and  mitigation 
measures  of  the  Coal  Mine  Methane  Development  Project  (CMMDP)  in  Shanxi  Province, 
People’s Republic of China (PRC). This document is based on environmental evaluations and 
assessments prepared for individual subproject proponents, which include field sampling and 
assessment, interviews, and analysis of secondary data. 
 
B.  Project Description 
 
2.  The proposed CMMDP includes (i) improved and expanded coal mine methane (CMM) 
and coalbed methane (CBM)1 production at the Jincheng Anthracite Mining Group Company 
Limited (JMC) mining areas, totaling approximately 182 million cubic meters a year (m3/year), 
which will be used to fire a 120-megawatt (MW) power plant; 22 kilometers (km) of 110 kilovolt 
power transmission line and four transformer substations will be constructed to deliver power to 
the grid; (ii) construction and operation of gas transmission and distribution networks to deliver 
approximately  166  million  m3/year  of  CMM,  with  an  average  methane  content  of  50%  to 
Jincheng City, including Yangcheng county; and (iii) institutional strengthening of the project 
implementing agencies (PIAs). CMM will be produced from existing mines, and CBM will be 
produced from new surface wells; new mining is not required.  
 
C.  Description of the Environment 
 
3.  Shanxi is on the middle reaches of the Yellow River in north-central PRC. It is about 
156,300 square kilometers (km2) in area, with a population of 32.97 million in 2000. It has a dry 
and windy spring, a wet summer, and a cold winter. The wet season is from July to September, 
when flooding is prevalent in the low-lying areas, particularly in the Yellow River Basin.   
 
4.  The CMMDP is in Jincheng county in the mountainous region of southeast Shanxi, close 
to the border with Henan Province. The topography is dominated by limestone mountains and 
plateaus covered by loess. Jincheng is in the southeast of the Shanxi plateau, which is higher in 
the east and lower in the central area. The urban center is in the catchment area of the Qin and 
Dan rivers, characterized by medium-relief rolling hills and basins. Mountains and rolling hills 
over 800 meters above sea level occupy 87.1% of the total land. The Gaoping Basin, Jincheng 
Basin, and Qin River valley are Jincheng’s economic and political centers. Seismic activity is 
rare and of low intensity (under grade IV). All facilities will be designed to withstand grade-VI 
incidents. 
 
5.  The Qin River is 458 km long, and flows into the Yellow River, with a highly variable 
seasonal  flow  of  2.5–3,050  cubic  meters  per  second  (m3/sec).  There  are  three  seasonal 
tributaries within 5 km of the site: the Mazhuang, Pan, and Changzhuang rivers.2 The water 
quality  generally  falls  within  class-IV  standards.  During  the  rainy  season,  erosion  of  the 
surrounding land can lead to very high concentrations of suspended solids in the rivers, which 
can lead to restrictions in the flow and consequent flooding.

refractory clay, gallium, and zeolite. Shanxi is the largest coal-producing province in the PRC.

ceramics, and power generation. The main air pollution sources in Jincheng are industry, coal,

1.  Project Alternatives 
 
12.  Without the CMMDP, the area will continue to rely on coal as the primary energy source 
for commercial, industrial, and residential use. Other energy options have not been developed 
on a commercial scale in the project area. Demand-side management measures will continue to 
be driven by market forces, but will be insufficient in the near term to offset increasing energy 
demands.  CMM  and  CBM  are  readily  available  alternatives,  the  supply  of  which  can  be 
expanded through improved production methods.  
 
2.  Coal Mine and Methane Gas Safety 
 
13.   The safety record of the PRC coal industry is poor and considerable efforts are being 
made to improve its performance, including closure of small mines over the last few years. In 
2002, 6121 deaths were reported, a rise of 8% over 2001. This is equivalent to 4.7 deaths per 
million tons of coal mined. Specific statistics for Shanxi are not available. The reported figures 
are believed to underestimate the extent of worker injuries and fatalities, as accidents in small 
and  illegal  mines  often  go  unreported.  Occupational  diseases  such  as  coal  worker's 
pneumoconiosis and silicosis are likely to be endemic amongst miners, but statistics for the 
project area are not available. 
 
14.  The risks associated with CMM and CBM extraction are low compared to actual coal 
mining. The explosion hazards associated with coal mining will be reduced. Enhanced CMM 
and CBM production will reduce mine explosion hazard by reducing the amount of methane gas 
in the mine working space. Using the predicted coal savings via replacement with CMM and 
CBM, the CMMDP is estimated to save about five lives per year. The draining of CBM from 
mines will make coal production safer. Injuries and occupational disease should be reduced with 
the CMMDP, but statistics are not available to perform a valid evaluation. 
 
15.  Gas leakage from pipeline transmission and distribution systems will be minimized by 
design,  following  best  engineering,  construction,  and  operating  practices.  Methane  and 
hydrogen sulfide (H S) are monitored by automated systems that trigger alarms when methane

PROJECT ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Demand Forecast and Least-Cost Generation Plan 
 
1.  In 2000, electricity consumption in the Shanxi power grid increased by 10%, following by 
11.2%  in  2001,  and  12.6%  in  2002.  The  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA) 
consultants produced a demand forecast for electricity consumption in the Shanxi power grid. 
Forecast was made for the short term (3 years) and the long term (up to 2020) on a sector 
basis. The demand-side management measures, including implementation of time-of-day tariffs 
based on the long-run marginal cost, were taken into account in the short- and long-term 
forecasts.  The  projected  growth  rates  of  electricity  demand  vary  for  different  consumer 
categories, the highest being in construction and the lowest in agriculture. Electricity demand in 
gigawatt-hours is conservatively forecast to grow at 8.1% for 2002–2005, 7.0% for 2006–2010, 
6.9% for 2011–2015, and 6.8% for 2016–2020.  
 
2.  Based on the energy demand forecast, the PPTA consultants carried out least-cost 
generation expansion planning using the generator of electric system planning model. The power 
generation options used in conjunction with plants under construction included 300 megawatts 
(MW) and 600 MW coal-fired power-generating units, gas turbine power plants, and combined-
cycle power plants. The analysis shows that the planned commissioning of the coal mine 
methane (CMM)-fired power plant at the Sihe mine under the Coalmine Methane Development 
Project (CMMDP) in 2006 (60 MW) and 2008 (60 MW) is supported by the least-cost generation 
expansion plan for the Shanxi power grid. The analysis used constant 2003 prices and a discount 
rate of 12%. Tradable commodities were valued at border prices at the prevailing exchange rate 
(CNY8.3=  $1.0).  Non-tradable  commodities  were  valued  at  shadow  prices,  using  a  mix  of 
standard and specific conversion factors.1  
 
3.  Two  least-cost  generation  expansion  alternatives  for  the  Shanxi  power  grid  were 
considered. Alternative I is the base case, which is to construct the CMM-fired power plant and 
transmission lines to connect the plant to the Shanxi power grid. In alternative II, the CMM-fired 
power plant will not be constructed; instead, 120 MW of coal-fired thermal power plant in the 
JMC operational areas is considered to meet the load requirement. The present values of cost 
flows (discounted to 2003 prices) for alternatives I and II are CNY169.583 and CNY169.655 
billion,  respectively.  The  results  indicate  that  the  least-cost  generation  expansion  scenario 
including the CMMDP compares favorably with the one without the CMMDP.  
 
4.  The  result  of  the  least-cost  analysis  is  supported  by  equalizing  discount  rate  (EDR) 
analysis.2 In the EDR analysis (Table A11.1), the CMM-fired power plant will replace coal-fired 
thermal for base load operation. The analysis compares the investment and operation cost of 
the 106 MW CMM-fired power plant with that of 120 MW coal-fired thermal (the capacity 
difference is due to different plant consumption rate and forced outage rate (FOR) between the 
CMM-fired power plant and the coal-fired thermal power plant). The main assumptions for the 
candidates, including the fuel cost and capital cost, were found to be appropriate. The results of 
an environmental impact were also incorporated into the EDR analysis. The EDR shows that the 
CMM-fired power plant is superior up to a discount rate of 14.4%, compared with the alternative of 
locating the coal-fired thermal power plant in the load center.

B.  Economic Internal Rate of Return 
 
5.  The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) calculations include (i) the CMM-fired power 
plant  and  production  of  CMM  and  coalbed  methane  (CBM),  (ii) CMM  transmission  and 
distribution pipeline systems, and (iii) the whole CMMDP including all components. The benefits 
of the CMMDP mainly include (i) incremental electricity and gas outputs, and more efficient gas 
supply; (ii) cost savings from meeting existing demand; and (iii) environmental benefits. As in 
the least-cost analysis, the economic analysis applied the conversion factors to investment 
costs  for  land,3 generation,  transmission,  and  distribution;  fuel  costs;  and  operation  and 
maintenance costs, where applicable. For the EIRR calculations, the benefits of energy output 
were valued based on consumer's willingness to pay, economic prices of gas and end-consumer 
tariffs. 
 
6.  An economic evaluation of the environmental impacts of the CMMDP was carried out 
based on the benefits transfer method. The evaluation used (i) methodology adopted in the 
Asian Development Bank’s Workbook on Economic Evaluation of Environmental Impacts (1996) 
to determine the adjusted estimate of the monetary damages caused by air pollution during the 
study period, taking into account the location of the CMM-fired power plant, the emission level, 
and the population affected; and (ii) estimates of average annual climate change for carbon 
emissions to evaluate the monetary damage caused by greenhouse gas emissions.  
 
7.  The EIRR calculation is a conservative approach, as it takes into account only the main 
benefits of different components but includes all CMMDP-related costs. As presented in Tables 
A11.2 to 4, taking the local environmental benefits into account, this approach yields an EIRR of 
21.1% for the component that include the CMM-fired power plant and the production of CMM 
and  CBM,  27.5%  for  the  component  that  includes  the  CMM  transmission  and  distribution 
pipeline systems, and 23.4% for the whole CMMDP. Sensitivity analyses were performed for the 
above EIRRs. For the EIRR of the whole CMMDP, sensitivity analysis showed that the EIRR 
would decrease to (i) 19.3% if the CMMDP were to experience a cost overrun of 20%; (ii) 15.3% 
if  the  benefits  were  reduced  by  20%;  (iii)  20.8%  if  the  CMMDP  were  to  experience  a 
commissioning delay of one year; and (iv) 10.6% if (i), (ii), and (iii) all occurred.  
 
8.  If the global environmental benefits were added to the benefits of the CMMDP, the EIRR 
for the CMM-fired power plant and the production of CMM and CBM would increase to 30.9%, 
the EIRR for CMM transmission and distribution pipeline systems would increase to 42.1%, and 
the EIRR for the whole CMMDP would increase to 34.6%.

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in the People’s Republic of China (PRC): 
 
In line with the Government’s energy sector strategy to promote socioeconomic development and to meet the basic 
needs of the poor, increased clean energy supply is needed to support the national poverty reduction program. 
Adequate and clean energy supply is seen as essential to human well-being and a crucial enabler of economic 
activities. The supply of coal mine methane (CMM) and coalbed methane (CBM) will decrease the coal burning that 
causes serious environmental and air-related diseases, particularly reduce the impacts on the poor, women and 
children who suffer most. The increased gas supply to local industries and commercial users will enable many 
enterprises to expand production and increase the quality and values of products, which in turn will create more 
employment and income opportunities for the local population and generate more tax revenues for the Shanxi 
provincial government to enhance its poverty reduction efforts. The improved urban environment can improve the local 
investment climate to attract more investment to the region and promote the growth of industry and service sectors. 
Through careful design of project subcomponents and proactive policy dialogue, the CMM Development  Project 
(CMMDP) provides free gas connection and tariff subsidy to the poor so that they can have access to the clean energy 
for their daily life. Moreover, the CMMDP will improve the safety of coal miners, who are mostly the poor people and 
improve the quality of life for the local people. Overall, the supply of clean CMM will complement the poverty reduction 
efforts in the Shanxi Province. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                     Targeting Classification: General intervention 
Poverty analysis has been conducted as an integral part of project planning and design and with the use of 
quantitative and qualitative methodologies. Various poverty data have been used in the analysis at national, provincial, 
municipal,  and  subproject  levels  through  field  poverty  assessments,  questionnaire  surveys  and  stakeholder 
consultations, including with the project beneficiaries and affected people, and secondary data collection. Extensive 
participatory methods have been used to assess the local poverty situation and energy needs of the poor. Policy 
dialogue has been undertaken to form a comprehensive poverty reduction and social strategy for the CMMDP that 
includes the following key components: 
 
1.  Providing clean energy supply to the poor: The CMMDP will directly benefit a total urban population of about 
410,000 in the project beneficiary area of Jincheng. Of the total beneficiary population, about 53,670 people or 
about 13.1% of the total beneficiaries belong to the poor measured by the local urban poverty lines. The 
increased use of CMM is expected to decrease the use of conventional fuels such as raw coal and coal briquettes 
that cause serious environmental and health impacts, which will indirectly benefit the entire population (particular 
for the poor) residing in the municipality of Jincheng, which is home to about 221,500 of rural poor based on the 
poverty line of CNY1,000 and about 97,000 urban poor who have an annual per-capita net income of less than 
CNY1,800 (weighted average) for urban areas. 
 
2.  Creating jobs for the poor: The construction of the CMMDP will create about 1,200 full-time jobs during 
construction and 845 during operation. Of these, about 780 full-time jobs for the poor and women with an 
estimated CNY8.5 million wage payment will go to the poor and women during construction and 420 full-time jobs 
during operations or CNY4.6 million of the wage payments per year are expected to go to the poor and women. In 
addition, local procurement of the materials required for the program is expected to create additional jobs. 
 
3.  Reducing air pollution and air-related diseases for the poor: The development and increase of CMM and 
CBM supplies and use will reduce air pollution by replacing the energy supplies from the coal-fired thermal power

urban areas. The CMMDP will substantially reduce the consumption of coal by an estimated 429,000 tons a year
